Award.AwardTitle: Examining the Career Trajectories of Urban Math Teachers from a Selective Alternative Certification Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of the research project is to describe the features of selective alternative teacher certification programs (ATCPs) that affect selective route mathematics teachers' (SRMT) professional pathways and to make informed recommendations to decrease the current high teacher turnover. While selective ATCPs are intended to address issues of teacher staffing and quality by recruiting high achieving graduates of the nation's most competitive colleges and career changers with impressive resumes, there is little understanding about the reasons for their mixed outcomes. Thus, the proposed project will utilize a multi-methodological longitudinal design that incorporates cultural-mathematical and sociological perspectives to 1) determine patterns of career trajectories of a representative sample of SRMTs and 2) examine how variations in the features of a selective ATCP affect SRMT retention. The results of the study will be useful to various stakeholders, including policymakers, district and school leaders, and directors of urban-specific teacher preparation programs by clarifying patterns in the career trajectories of SRMTs while also revealing how to retain them..

The study is framed by the literature on teacher turnover, alternative teacher certification programs, and teachers' professional life cycles. It is guided also by two theoretical perspectives, namely a sociological careership perspective used to examine SRMTs' career trajectories and a cultural-mathematical perspective that identifies the features of selective ATCPs that influence SMRT retention. The researchers will combine new survey and interview data with previously collected data on New York City Teaching Fellows (NYCTF) to produce findings that could inform the development of mathematics teacher preparation programs and interventions for an improved urban mathematics teaching force.

The project is supported by the ECR program that emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development. ECR supports the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to understand, build theory to explain, and suggest intervention and innovations to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning and participation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study examines the career trajectories and performance of secondary math teachers who entered public school teaching in the prior decade through the New York City Teaching Fellows (NYCTF) program, a selective alternative teacher certification program (ATCP). The Teaching Fellows and similar programs are considered selective because they seek high achieving graduates from the nation’s most selective colleges and report rejecting far more applicants than they admit. Over the past two decades, more than 100,000 teachers, including over 10,000 secondary mathematics teachers, have entered teaching through selective ATCPs.

Two major goals of this multi-methodological study are to examine:
1) the career trajectories of mathematics teachers who began NYCTF in 2006 and 2007;
2) how the major components of NYCTF (i.e., teacher selection, training, fieldwork, school assignments, mentoring and induction) affect the program outcomes of mathematics teacher retention, effectiveness, preparedness, beliefs, and instruction.

The project shows that NYCTF has largely failed to close the gaps in teacher effectiveness, retention, quality, and diversity that it was designed to close (Brantlinger et al., under review, in press). Across multiple indicators, it is clear that NYCTF either has maintained or exacerbated gaps in critical areas due both to flaws in the program’s theory of action and also the fidelity of implementation of this theory. This study also adds to the growing evidence that the graduates of very selective colleges do not make more effective teachers than the teachers they teach alongside in high-poverty schools (Brantlinger et al., under review; Brantlinger & Griffin, 2019).

At the same time, there is considerable within-program variations training, induction, and outcomes like retention and effectiveness. To better understand this, the project included an intersectional quantitative analysis which examines how teacher selection, training, and school assignments interactively shaped participants’ early-career retention outcomes (Brantlinger et al., under review). This study showed that, in influencing retention, fast-track training for secondary mathematics: (1) has both long- and short-term effects on teachers’ district and school retention, (2) operates differentially on different teacher subgroups working in particular school contexts, and (3) depends on the substance – and not just the fast-track structure – of this training. At a broader level, the results indicate that we will not find “proven” approaches to preparation - approaches that work well for all, or even most, teacher candidates irrespective of their backgrounds, orientations, and teaching context.

There are clear implications of the project for policy and practice. In particular, to improve mathematics teacher retention and/or effectiveness: (1) large school districts, and the teacher preparation programs that serve them, should do more to recruit, select, and develop local teacher talent, particularly Black teachers; (2) to improve retention and effectiveness, districts and programs should increase the quality and quantity of early-career mentoring and induction for mathematics teachers; and (3) that teacher preparation should be tailored to different types of teacher candidates as some seem to benefit more from mathematics-specific training and others from “practical” and subject-general training (with a focus on classroom management).
